ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Remote independent research lab project
virtual lab work supplemented with some in-person instruction and experimentation
independent genetics/computational research conducted on my own schedule
In-person or virtual research
We held our weekly lab meetings over Zoom, but I was in-lab most of the semester. If I wasn't in lab, I was remotely working on research by reading papers etc.
In person lab as well as remote data analysis.
We also did Zoom lab meetings and journal club.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Independent research
Gained research design and scientific writing skills, in addition to technical skills in my specific project area (computational design and molecular modeling)
learned more about research techniques and methods

My work got shifted from wet lab to computational work. I learned how to code in R, to analyze TCR and RNAseq datasets, create nice plots, etc. I also learned how to think like a scientist planning an experiment.
independent research experience
Conducting experiments in the laboratory, scientific writing, collaborating with members in lab
individual research

I learned so much about Drosophila and how exactly polyQ diseases work as well as their histories; focusing on SCA1 and SBMA on the side. I finally understood a lot of the techniques we use in lab and what purpose they held such as why we image only the eye in Drosophila: because that is how we can interpret nuerodegneration as expressed in the eye.
I learned MATLAB coding, and am continuing to build on that. I've also honed my neurosurgical skills (on mice) for our research purposes and can operate independently.

Research at the Joshi lab is one of the most valuable courses Ive done at Yale. Ive learned how to think like a scientist, how to develop experiments, how to present data and work, how to maintain a lab notebook, how to work on a team, etc. (The list goes on)

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Clearer guidelines about reports

Strengths include the open-ended design, good faculty support, and that research is a great way to learn hands on
Only weakness is course instructors in the MCDB department left out some formatting requirements and other information and individuals needed to email them to clarify these areas (in other words, course expectations were not always clearly laid out for the two written submissions)

As usual I enjoyed my time in the lab but we received no feedback on the proposals we submitted for the course itself. Once again this major continues to have us guess as to what the exact expectations are and how were meant to write about science I was hoping to get feedback or further guidance that could be helpful for grad school in a couple years. Hopefully we'll get feedback in the spring version of this course.

I appreciate the freedom that the MCDB department gives us to conduct research, but there is very little guidance on the part of the MCDB 485 instructors, meaning your experience doing research will mostly depend on the lab youre in and the mentor/PI you have. Perhaps check-ins, or other strategies to see if the students are managing alright would be nice.

Strengths: students had instructor support if they needed it. Very self-driven, "pick-your-own-pace" type of course.
Weaknesses: no feedback, sometimes was hard to tell if I was doing what I needed to do
Having an organized syllabus with due dates might be helpful in the future.
hard during COVID, but very flexible :)
I think this course could be improved by providing more concrete information about due dates and the components/organization of each assignment.

This semester was relatively busy in lab with work as well as writing a review, so a strength was that I gained a lot of knowledge in a short amount of time just by reading so many papers alone. In addition, I learned more about the Drosophila as a model organism when I used to focus on mice. I hope that next semester I can learn how to quantify the data we got and will continue to get through the rest of the school year.
Pretty straight forward lay out and easy to follow.

The strengths of this course are the lab members themselves. My PI and mentor are great teachers and were very involved in my learning. The other lab members in the Joshi lab also provided incredible support and advice.
No camaraderie in major, no example papers, very little effort from course coordinations except to make things arbitrarily difficult.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: My personal experience was fantastic as my lab found me a very complete remote project (using molecular modeling software). However, this largely depends on your individual lab
They allowed an option to analyze data rather than do in person wet lab workthat was helpful. Also, the option to substitute this requirement for MCDB 350+ classes was good.
hard to get into the lab to work given limitations on bench space/time

I think that the weekly zoom meetings worked very well as we could still meet up virtually from home and see all the member's faces and coordinate. The only improvement would be allowing students lab entry earlier on, but I understand that with quarantine this is difficult and near impossible.
The move to make lab meetings and journal clubs over zoom was effective and safe. Mask mandates and social distancing practices within labs were effective and safe as well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes

Yes, although your individual experience depends almost entirely on your lab. I had an incredible experience, but this was because my lab mentors found a very good project (adapted to remote learning) and were very supportive. I've heard of other students having more mixed experiences, so it really depends on the mentor you find for yourself. Overall, I greatly enjoyed performing research for credit as it is totally different than a normal class and it was nice to have more open-ended work. In my lab, my workload was not too challenging. However, other labs' projects may be more demanding. The requirements for the fall semester include a 2 page proposal after the first week, an informal presentation during your lab's weekly meetings, and a 5 page proposal at the end of the semester. There assignments helped me learn and were not too hard to do but there was no specific feedback from the course instructors, which would have been nice.
If you like doing research, sure.
If you have a good lab and a good mentor, yes.
It's a good experience and culmination of the MCDB major. I've learned a lot and grown much more confident in a lab setting through this opportunity than through other lab courses.
Yes I recommend this course to any MCDB student who wants to do research while at Yale
Yes, I would recommend the senior thesis, especially in my lab as you will gain experience in the lab setting as well as hone your skill sin scientific writing.
Yes, for one it is required of MCDB majors. But aside from that, independent research may be the best way to learn how to do research (as long as you have a good mentor in your PI).
Yes. Research provides excellent experience and very detailed and interactive learning.
